sections.summary: Disbelievers are described as steeped in **arrogance** and **defiance**, ridiculing the message of the **One God** and the status of the Prophet [547–548]. They question the divine choice of the warner and are warned that they have not yet tasted the **punishment** associated with the treasuries of mercy.

Past nations such as Noah, Aad, and Pharaoh are cited as **confederates** who denied messengers and consequently deserved retribution. The text warns that current deniers can expect only a single **scream** from which there is no recovery, despite their requests to hasten their share of the **Day of Account**.

sections.theme: The Resourcefulness and Judgment of David
sections.summary: David is honored as a resourceful servant whose kingdom was strengthened by Allah and accompanied by mountains and birds in **glorification** [548–549]. The narrative of the two disputants over **ewes** serves as a test, reminding rulers to judge with **justice** and avoid following **desire**.

Allah establishes that the heavens and earth were not created in **vain**, refuting the assumptions of disbelievers who are warned of the **Fire**. The Scripture is identified as a **blessed Book** intended for those with intelligence to ponder its verses and distinguish between the righteous and the **shameless**.

Solomon is gifted as an excellent, penitent servant who is tested after his preoccupation with **horses** led to a lapse in **remembrance** [549–550]. After seeking **forgiveness**, he is granted a unique kingdom with control over the **wind and demons**, establishing his high rank and nearness to Allah.

Job’s appeal for mercy during his affliction by **Satan** is answered with the provision of a cooling spring for **healing**. He is recognized as an excellent, patient servant who remained **obedient** to his Lord throughout his trials [550–551].

This range commemorates prophets like Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, Ishmael, Elisha, and Ezekiel for their **vision** and dedication to the **remembrance of the Home**. These individuals are distinguished as the **outstanding** chosen servants of Allah.

The **devout** are promised eternal bliss in the **Gardens of Eden**, characterized by wide-open doors and modesty. In contrast, the **transgressors** face a miserable return to Hell, where they will feud and experience diverse torments for their **wrongdoing** [551–552].

sections.theme: Absolute Monotheism and the Rebellion of Iblis
sections.summary: The Messenger is commanded to proclaim **Allah as the One** and recount the creation of man and the subsequent expulsion of **Satan (Iblis)** for his **pride**. The surah concludes by identifying the Quran as a universal **reminder** whose truth will be realized by all humanity after a while.
